Now for the "count-assert" mechanism: I don't think that adding a 
plug-in is the way to go.  The easiest way is to declare a static 
variable in the Assert class.  This variable is accessible by the 
CoreRunner and adding methods to handle this variable in the CoreRunner 
object is not a problem.
</smip>

But doesn't this break your code every time you upgrade JUnit?  I thought
the point of a plug-in was that you could upgrade without having to make any
code changes.

Donald Holliday

>to integrate and play nicely with each others. It's a simple enough thing
(I
>think) that it should not be impossible to do.
>
I have studied the pluggability in JUnit and developped a first 
prototype.  What I have done is creating a basic runner that separates 
TextRunner and UIRunner from the JUnit core business.  My experience is 
that it requires some changes but it is absolutely feasible.

If you are familiar with the internal JUnit business, here is how it works:
- the CoreRunner registeres itself as a TestListener to the TestResult 
(in fact there is now only one TestListener)
- Plug-in modules register themselves as CoreListener to the CoreRunner
- TestListener's events are passed to the plug-ins via the CoreListener 
interface
- new events (like when the runner starts/stops running the tests) are 
also passed via the CoreListener interface

Now for the "count-assert" mechanism: I don't think that adding a 
plug-in is the way to go.  The easiest way is to declare a static 
variable in the Assert class.  This variable is accessible by the 
CoreRunner and adding methods to handle this variable in the CoreRunner 
object is not a problem.

-Vladimir
